ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, Pablo points out in his report that sharpneat s crossover method has an execution path in which all excess and disjoint genes (connections) on the weaker

Subject: Crossover - excess and disjoint genes
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=IqbpKhlPsCAfC6mLf1GeYPaT7IUQ_KEdaaVee46ujnzpZ6D1o6fN
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Hi,

Pablo points out in his report that sharpneat's crossover method has
an execution path in which all excess and disjoint genes (connections)
on the weaker of the two parents are copied to the offspring genome.

That path is controlled by a configurable probability that defaults to
50%, so half the time we get all the excess/disjoint, the other half
we get none (just a mix of connection weights on the matching genes).

I suspect we've discussed this in the distant past, but does anyone
have a view on this approach? E.g. with respect to biology?

 - Colin
